Award.AwardTitle: Research in Classical and Quantum Gravity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports research in gravitational physics at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Many of the deepest problems in theoretical physics revolve around combining Einstein's theory of general relativity with quantum theory. The resulting theory is called "quantum gravity" and is needed to better understand the origin of the universe, the nature of space and time on small scales, and what happens inside black holes. The research supported by this award will use the latest techniques and tools to try to answer some of these fundamental problems. An essential part of this project is the training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in the knowledge and techniques that are central to understanding and discovery in gravitational physics. Through a range of forums from public lectures, to informing media reporters, the Principal Investigators will disseminate the directions and results of their research to a broad audience. Society at large will benefit by increasing their understanding of science and the world they live in.

James Hartle will continue exploring the interface between quantum mechanics and cosmology. He will work on extending the predictions of the no-boundary quantum state of the universe for observations today to increasingly general and detailed situations. He will further develop the generalizations of quantum mechanics that are necessary for cosmology and investigate cosmologically motivated extensions of quantum mechanics. He proposes to continue to refine our understanding of the origin of the quasiclassical realm of every day experience as an emergent feature of our quantum universe. Gary Horowitz will investigate physics near cosmological singularities in holographic theories of quantum gravity. These are theories in which quantum gravitational degrees of freedom are equivalently described by a lower dimensional nongravitational theory. Horowitz will also explore connections between gravity and condensed matter that can arise using a classical limit of holography. This provides a new tool for the study of superconductivity and other phenomena. In addition, Horowitz will investigate aspects of higher dimensional black holes. Don Marolf will explore a variety of issues in classical and quantum gravity related to black holes, thermodynamics, and entropy. One is to extend arguments that black holes are thermodynamic systems to more general situations. Another is to investigate the possibility that the area of more general surfaces in spacetime might also be associated with entropy, and that spacetime itself may exist only due to thermodynamic phenomena. A final part of his work will continue to study implications of a quantum-mechanical phenomenon (the so-called Hawking effect) that causes black holes to slowly evaporate and which may require significant changes in our understanding of fundamental physics. The methods employed for all this work will be primarily analytic, though it will be supplemented with numerical calculations on desktop computers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most remarkable developments in theoretical physics is gauge/gravity duality which relates a theory of gravity with certain boundary conditions (known as anti-de Sitter or AdS) to a nongravitational theory.  A key feature of this correspondence is that AdS has a boundary that is located an infinite distance away but which can be treated as a spacetime in its own right. A highlight of Marolf's results from this grant is a paper with Kraus and Liu clarifying shortcomings of a proposed expansion of this duality to cases where the boundary is located at a finite distance from the bulk. A highlight of Horowitz's work from this grant is a paper with Engelhardt that provides a new way to recover the gravitational description from the nongravitational one.

Marolf also worked with students Fu and Grado-White to develop the theory of traversable wormholes.  In classical general relativity, wormholes necessarily collapse faster than any observer can travel through them.  This is guaranteed by the so-called topological censorship theorems.  But some wormholes are almost traversable in the sense that there is a pair of light rays such that one enters the wormhole on one side, the other exits the wormhole on the other side, and the two rays are separated by an arbitrarily small distance in the middle. This raises the possibility that tiny quantum effects can render the wormhole traversable, at least briefly.  Building on previous work by Gao, Jafferis, and Wall allowed Marolf's group to show that back-reaction from natural quantum states can indeed cause a wide variety of wormholes to become traversable when the wormholes are otherwise isolated from other effects.

A longstanding conjecture in general relativity is cosmic censorship, which states that generic gravitational collapse cannot produce regions of arbitrarily strong gravitational fields that are visible to distant observers. Horowitz and Santos wrote a series of papers showing that this conjecture can be violated in theories of gravity with AdS boundary conditions. They also showed that when charged particles are present in the theory (as they are in nature) cosmic censorship is preserved. This led to a surprising connection between cosmic censorship and another conjecture about quantum gravity known as the weak gravity conjecture.

Hartle, often with the collaboration of Thomas Hertog, continued a program of understanding the universe as a quantum mechanical system - a quantum cosmology. In particular, he used simple models to predict probabilities for how today's classical universe emerged from its quantum start 14 billion years ago using theories of the universe's quantum state and dynamics. Among the specific issues addressed were:  How the universe can make quantum transitions between patches of classical spacetime.  How to make quantitative predictions for observations when the universe is undergoing rapid and uncontrolled (eternal) inflation. He described how to formulate quantum theory when the observer is inside the system rather than outside it. With Hertog and Halliwell, Hartle provided a more secure formulation of the no-boundary wave function of the universe that he and Stephen Hawking originally proposed. He showed how a multiverse of classical spacetimes arises naturally and inevitably in a quantum universe. He used these developments to predict the results of our large scale observations of the universe that can be used to test the theory.
